﻿Coal will probably rival oil as the world’s biggest source of energy in the next five years. This might be a disaster for the climate.
One of the biggest reasons behind the rise in coal use is the big increase in the use of shale gas in the US.
New research from the International Energy Agency (IEA) shows that all over the world people are using more coal, except in the US, where shale gas is now more popular than coal. Because the US is using less coal, coal prices across the world have reduced. This has made coal more attractive, even in Europe.
Maria van der Hoeven, Executive Director of the IEA, said that the amount of coal we use “continues to grow each year and, if no changes are made, coal will catch oil within ten years.”
Coal is available in large amounts and it can be found in most regions of the world, unlike oil and gas, and it is cheap to extract. The IEA says that China and India will drive world coal use in the next five years, and India will probably overtake the US as the world’s second biggest consumer. China is the biggest coal importer, and Indonesia is the biggest coal exporter.
According to the IEA’s Medium-Term Coal Market Report, the world will burn 1.2bn more tonnes of coal per year by 2017 compared with today.
With the highest carbon emissions, coal makes climate change a lot worse, especially when it is burned in old-fashioned, inefficient power stations. Coal can also produce sulphur emissions – these lead to acid rain – and mercury and soot-particle pollution.
Van der Hoeven says that we should make coal more expensive so that people prefer to use cleaner technologies such as renewable power. Providing cheaper gas is the only way to reduce demand for coal. This has happened in the US because of the big increase in the production of shale gas there in the past five years.
She said: “The US experience suggests that a more efficient gas market can reduce coal use, carbon dioxide emissions and electricity bills. Europe, China and other regions should take note.”
If something isn’t done soon there will be more climate change.

Furthermore, according to recent analyses by the International Energy Agency (IEA), worldwide coal consumption has escalated across various regions, particularly in China and India, with notable exceptions such as the United States, where shale gas has supplanted coal as the preferred energy source. This transition has led to a decline in domestic coal prices due to increased shale gas utilization, making it economically advantageous for other nations, including Europe.

The IEA’s Medium-Term Coal Market Report forecasts an increase of 1.2 billion additional tonnes of coal burned annually by 2017. Global coal consumption is expected to rise significantly, with China and India leading this trend. Specifically, while economic factors drive the rise in coal production, geopolitical concerns such as energy security play a significant role.

Moreover, according to recent analyses by the International Energy Agency (IEA), worldwide coal consumption has escalated across various regions, particularly in China and India, where domestic coal prices have declined due to increased shale gas utilization. This trend is expected to continue, making coal increasingly cost-effective and economically advantageous for other nations, including Europe.

Given these concerns, Maria van der Hoeven, Executive Director of the IEA, advocates for policies that increase the cost of coal, thereby encouraging a shift towards cleaner alternatives like renewable energy sources. She urges Europe, China, and other regions to adopt similar strategies promptly, as the U.S. experience demonstrates that enhancing gas market efficiency can significantly reduce coal consumption.

Failure to act swiftly will likely result in accelerated climate change, underscoring the urgency of implementing effective mitigation measures such as policies that increase the cost of coal. For example, carbon pricing or cap-and-trade systems can help reduce coal usage by making it more economically unattractive compared to cleaner energy sources. The United States' experience demonstrates that enhancing gas market efficiency can significantly reduce coal consumption, carbon dioxide emissions, and electricity costs.

The combustion of coal in older facilities can lead to a notable escalation in particulate matter, which not only affects air quality but also poses significant health risks due to increased exposure to mercury and soot particles. For instance, the IEA's report highlights that the combustion of coal in outdated power plants contributes significantly to acid rain formation through sulfur emissions and releases major pollutants such as mercury and soot into the atmosphere.

For example, carbon pricing or cap-and-trade systems can help reduce coal usage by making it more economically unattractive compared to cleaner energy sources. The United States' experience demonstrates that enhancing gas market efficiency can significantly reduce coal consumption, carbon dioxide emissions, and electricity costs.

Google has made maps of the world’s highest mountains, the ocean floor, the Amazon rainforest and even shown us a bit of North Korea. They want to make maps of the whole world, but they have mostly stayed away from the Arctic.
Now, however, Google is starting a very important update to hundreds of years of polar map making – and it hopes that the map will help give a better understanding of life on the permafrost for millions of web users. A small Google team has flown to Iqaluit, the largest town in the Canadian territory of Nunavut. They have taken their warmest winter clothes, many laptop computers and an 18kg telescopic camera that they can fix to their backpacks.
The team spent four days collecting the images and information that will give the isolated community on Baffin Island something that people across the world who live in cities now take for granted. An Inuit mapping expert helped the Google team and curious locals followed them around.
The town of 7,000 people will go on display via Google’s popular Street View application in July 2013.
When Google made maps of other parts of the world it used a special camera on a car roof. In Iqaluit that was not possible, so Google’s map makers walked the town’s snowy roads and trails. Some roads are made of ice and disappear in the short summer months.
The team also walked along part of a 15km road known as the Road to Nowhere, despite warnings about meeting polar bears.
The online map that Google had already created using satellite images was mostly correct, but one road was missing that had been built in the last year.
One difficulty was how to place on the map many businesses and homes that have mail sent to the local post office and not delivered to their address. Putting the PO box addresses on the map would mean the new map would show all the companies, banks and schools in the same place, around the Canada Post building in the centre of town.
About 30 Inuit elders, business people and high-school pupils helped Google to correct this problem. They were given a laptop computer and told how to make sure their homes, shops and meeting places would show up correctly on the map.
The project is more than a novelty. Arif Sayani, the town’s Director of Planning, said that people who are thinking of visiting or moving to the area would be able to use the maps to see the area. It may also help planning decisions in Iqaluit happen more quickly.
The project leader for Google said he hoped to see the work continue in other northern towns. But moving people and equipment around the vast Arctic territory is very expensive. So, in the future, Google might send equipment to the area and ask volunteers to complete the map.

However, they have largely refrained from exploring Arctic regions until now.

In this significant update to polar cartography, Google aims to enhance understanding of life in permafrost areas for millions of users worldwide. A dedicated team has embarked on an ambitious mission to Iqaluit, the largest settlement within Nunavut's territory, where they have donned warm protective attire and equipped themselves with multiple laptop computers and a 18 kg telescopic camera designed for backpacking.

Owing to weather conditions, terrain difficulties, and access limitations, they could not use a specialized camera mounted atop a vehicle. Instead, the team had to walk Iqaluit’s snowy streets and trails. Among their many obstacles was navigating the Road to Nowhere, a 15 km stretch notorious for its dangers, including encounters with polar bears, which posed significant risks.

Over four days, this group meticulously collected images and data that will provide residents of Baffin Island's isolated community with the same level of digital street view access enjoyed by city dwellers. Given the treacherous snow conditions, the team had no choice but to walk Iqaluit’s snowy streets and trails and navigate the Road to Nowhere, a 15 km stretch notorious for its dangers, including encounters with polar bears. These challenges posed significant risks.

An Inuit mapping specialist assisted in their efforts while local inhabitants observed their activities curiously. Furthermore, this project not only offers substantial benefits for future visitors and residents considering relocation but also provides valuable data for local planning decisions. For example, detailed information about the town's layout could expedite local planning decisions by enhancing future visitors' and residents' experiences.

﻿The auction of a Banksy painting that disappeared from the wall of a north London shop was stopped just moments before it was going to be sold.
Slave Labour is a spray-painted artwork that shows a child making flags. The expected price was about $700,000. It was going to be in a sale of street art in Florida.
But Frederic Thut, the owner of the Fine Arts Auction Miami art house said that Slave Labour and a second work by the secretive British street artist were removed from sale at the auction. He did not want to give the name of the seller.
People in Haringey, London, were very happy, because they led a campaign to stop the sale of the artwork that was removed from the wall of a Poundland shop in Haringey.
“I will write to the auction house to find out what will happen next, but for now we are really pleased that a people’s campaign in London has had an impact in the US. It’s a real victory for the people.” said Alan Strickland, a Haringey councillor.
The auction house said it had told the owners of the two Banksys that they should remove them from the sale. “There are no legal problems with the sale of the artwork by Banksy, but FAAM told its sellers they should remove them from the auction.”
Critics have said the auction house was buying and selling stolen property but Thut said that the seller was the real owner and that the sale was legal.
He added that his gallery had received many emails and phone calls from the UK, but said he thought it was right to sell the two pieces of artwork because it would keep them safe.
The second Banksy that was going to be auctioned was a 2007 artwork called Wet Dog that was removed from a Bethlehem wall. Its estimated price is up to $800,000.
Poundland said it had no idea who removed the 4ft x 5ft mural from the side of its shop.
Banksy himself has not commented on the sale of Slave Labour, but he has condemned people who have tried to sell his artwork in the past.
Stephan Keszler, the dealer at a 2011 auction in New York that also planned to sell Banky’s paintings, believes selling Banksy’s works without his permission is fair.
“He does something on other people’s walls and houses without asking. The owner of the property can do whatever they want with it,” Keszler said.

In response to this development, Councillor Alan Strickland conveyed his contentment by stating that he would correspond with the auction house, which had been influenced by a grassroots movement in London, to monitor future developments. Given our elation that a grassroots movement in London has influenced an American entity, leading to the cancellation of the disputed artwork from the auction, this is indeed a triumph for the community.

Thut maintained that his gallery had instructed the owners of the two Banksy artworks to withhold them from sale due to unspecified concerns. He argued that there were no legal impediments to selling the artwork by Banksy but advised the sellers to take off the market their pieces, maintaining that the transaction was lawful and that the seller was the legitimate owner.

Furthermore, Thut further maintained that his gallery had received numerous communications from the United Kingdom but deemed it appropriate to proceed with the sale as a means of safeguarding the artworks. The second Banksy piece scheduled for auction, which had been removed from a wall in Bethlehem and measured four by five feet, is particularly significant due to its historical context and unique artistic style.

Stephan Keszler, an expert in the field of auctioneering, who has extensive experience in legal and ethical considerations, argued that selling such works without the artist's consent is fair: "He operates on other people's walls and properties without seeking permission; thus, the property owner can do whatever they wish with it." ﻿The huge fortunes made by the world’s richest 100 billionaires are making inequality worse and stopping the world from being able to reduce poverty, says Oxfam.
Oxfam said the world could end poverty several times over if the richest 100 billionaires would give away the money they made in 2012.
The charity said that the $240bn made in 2012 by the richest 100 billionaires would be enough to end extreme poverty four times over.
It is unusual for charities to attack the wealthy, because they are usually seen as a source of money. Bill Gates and Warren Buffett are among a group of 40 US billionaires who have said they will give much of their money to aid projects, but there is little information about how much money they give each year.
Russian, Middle Eastern and Chinese billionaires do not give away money to charity in the same way that US billionaires do.
In the report, the charity asks world leaders to end income extremes and reduce inequality.
The report said that the richest 1% of people have increased their incomes by 60% in the past 20 years.
Barbara Stocking, Oxfam’s Chief Executive, said: “We can no longer pretend that wealth for a few people will benefit many people – too often the opposite is true.”
The report said the problem affected all parts of the world. “In the UK, inequality is returning to levels not seen since the nineteenth century. In China, the top 10% now earn nearly 60% of the income. Chinese inequality levels are now similar to those in South Africa, which is now the most unequal country on Earth.”
In the US, the share of national income that goes to the top 1% of people has doubled since 1980 from 10% to 20%, the report says.
The richest 1% are estimated to cause 10,000 times more pollution than the average US citizen.
Oxfam said world leaders should learn from countries such as Brazil, which has grown quickly and reduced inequality at the same time.
Stocking said that world leaders should agree to reduce inequality to the levels seen in 1990.
She said closing tax havens, which hold as much as $31 trillion, or as much as a third of all global wealth, could collect $189bn in additional taxes.
Rewritten Text:
The substantial accumulations of immense fortunes by the world's most affluent 100 billionaires are exacerbating global inequality and impeding efforts to alleviate poverty, according to Oxfam's findings. Specifically, these ultra-wealthy individuals generate their earnings through a variety of means, including investments in technology, real estate, and other sectors, which contribute significantly to this disparity.

Oxfam asserts that the $240 billion generated by the top 100 billionaires in 2012 would be sufficient to reduce global poverty by a factor of four. Typically, charities refrain from criticizing the wealthy, as they are often perceived as a source of financial support; however, notable exceptions include Bill Gates and Warren Buffett, who have pledged significant portions of their wealth to philanthropic endeavors. Nonetheless, detailed annual contributions remain scarce.

According to Oxfam's report, Russian, Middle Eastern, and Chinese billionaires exhibit distinct patterns of charitable giving that differ from those seen in their American counterparts. The organization posits that the wealthiest 1% has witnessed a 60% increase in income over the past two decades. In the United Kingdom, income disparities have reached levels not observed since the 19th century, with the top 10% now commanding nearly 60% of total earnings. Similarly, in China, the top 10% now command nearly 60% of total earnings, mirroring South African inequality levels, which are currently the highest globally.

In the United States, the share of national income accruing to the top 1% has doubled from 10% to 20% since 1980. As reported by Oxfam's findings, Barbara Stocking, Oxfam’s Chief Executive, further emphasized that it is no longer tenable to assume that wealth concentrated among a few will benefit the majority; often, it perpetuates socioeconomic deprivation.

Furthermore, as highlighted by Oxfam's report, global inequality manifests differently across regions. In the United Kingdom, income disparities have reached levels not observed since the 19th century, with the top 10% now commanding nearly 60% of total earnings, a figure that mirrors South African inequality levels, which are currently the highest globally. Similarly, in China, the top 10% now command nearly 60% of total earnings.

In Brazil, the report advocates for learning from countries that have experienced rapid economic growth while simultaneously reducing inequality. Specifically, as highlighted by Oxfam's findings, Barbara Stocking proposes that world leaders should aim to reduce inequality to levels observed in 1990 and suggests closing tax havens, which hold approximately $31 trillion or one-third of global wealth, could yield an additional $189 billion in taxes.

Source Text:
In 2005, BlackBerry brought instant messaging to the mobile phone and the company was just entering its period of success. Then, the iPhone was still just an idea and BlackBerry’s innovations made its smartphone one of Canada’s biggest exports.
Six years later, in the summer of 2011, there were riots in London and other UK cities. Rioters used BlackBerry Messenger (BBM) and politicians wanted the service to shut down. But, two years later, the users themselves are leaving BBM.
Fewer and fewer people want BlackBerry phones. There are now many alternative products, from Facebook’s and Apple’s instant messaging applications to independent apps such as WhatsApp and Kik (which is also Canadian). They are free to download and use, and they use the internet to swap text messages, pictures, voice clips, 'stickers' and even videos between most types of phones.
BBM is trying to keep its customers and you can now use it on Android and Apple phones. There are many other apps people can use, but lots of people want to use the BBM app – more than 20 million people downloaded it. But many people believe BBM will not survive. “The move to bring BlackBerry to the iPhone is four or five years too late,” says James Gooderson, a technology blogger. “WhatsApp has made BlackBerrys unnecessary for young people.”
BBM says it has 80 million monthly users after its upgrade, but WhatsApp has 300 million. Other services show BBM’s weaknesses: Skype and Viber have video or voice calls, but BBM doesn’t; Path does location sharing, but BBM doesn’t; there is no video sharing, as on iMessage; and the stickers (a more sophisticated version of the smiley face), that kids around the world adore, are also absent. Even the contacts and calendar sharing that BBM made possible on BlackBerry phones are not on the Apple and Android versions.
Messaging is now becoming visual. Photos that are uploaded to Instagram get instant comments and Snapchat’s pictures have opened a world of other possibilities. Like BBM, all of these services are free for any phone with an internet connection. But, in 2011, BBM was so powerful that it helped to start a revolution in Egypt; and at the time of the London riots, people used BBM, not their televisions, to find out quickly what was happening.
Nearly 80% of young smartphone owners regularly use a social networking application but two-thirds use more than one. 60% of 16- to 24-year-olds use Facebook every day, but 46% use alternatives. “It’s much more complex,” says Benedict Evans, a digital media specialist. “All of these apps use your smartphone. Apps rise and fall like fireworks. Some, like Instagram, last; others just disappear.”
Thirteen-year-old Bennett has three phones. He keeps his BlackBerry for messaging, he uses an iPhone to play games, and he makes phone calls on an Android phone. His friends are still on BBM. At the touch of a few buttons, you can send a single BlackBerry message to several hundred people; on WhatsApp, the limit is 50. But, for Bennett, Instagram is now a major social network. “Instagram is Facebook without parents,” he says. “Facebook is now for older people.” The low cost of buying and using a BlackBerry is still an advantage. Anyone with a second-hand phone and a £7-a-month deal from a telecoms company can use unlimited BBM messages. But people no longer trust the privacy of BBM. Business people, revolutionaries, demonstrators and rioters used to believe that their messages were secret. The arrests that followed the riots showed that wasn’t true.
In the rich London district of South Kensington, the older pupils at one school all have Apple phones. They all use WhatsApp. For many, BBM is a distant memory. “I still have a Blackberry, but I’m the only one,” says one teenager. And how does that make him feel? “Isolated,” he says.

Concurrently, the iPhone was merely an embryonic concept, and it was BlackBerry's pioneering innovations that made its devices one of Canada’s most significant exports.

Six years later, in the summer of 2011, civil unrest erupted across London and other UK cities. The rioters extensively utilized BlackBerry Messenger (BBM), prompting politicians to contemplate shutting down the service. However, two years hence, it was the users themselves who began switching to rival applications; for instance, many migrated away from BBM in favor of competitive services such as WhatsApp.

Despite BBM's efforts to expand compatibility with Android and Apple devices, many users have migrated to other applications, such as WhatsApp, which is free to download and use. For example, over 20 million people downloaded WhatsApp alone. Furthermore, despite BBM’s efforts to enhance its functionality, the transition of BlackBerry to the iPhone was four or five years too late, as James Gooderson, a technology blogger, opines.

In affluent areas like South Kensington, older pupils at one school predominantly use Apple phones and WhatsApp, a platform that offers features such as location sharing and video calls, which BBM lacks. For many, BBM is a distant memory. Moreover, despite BBM's claims of 80 million monthly active users following its recent upgrade, WhatsApp boasts an impressive user base of 300 million. Other services highlight BBM's shortcomings: Skype and Viber offer video or voice calls, whereas BBM does not; Path enables location sharing, a feature absent in BBM; there is no video sharing on BBM as seen with iMessage; and the stickers, which are adored by children worldwide, are notably missing. Even the contacts and calendar sharing capabilities that BBM once provided on BlackBerry phones are now unavailable on Android and iOS versions.

The landscape of messaging has transformed into a predominantly visual one. Photos uploaded to Instagram receive instant comments, while Snapchat's picture-sharing feature has opened up new possibilities. Like BBM, these services are free for any phone with an internet connection. However, in 2011, BBM played a pivotal role in initiating the Egyptian revolution and was instrumental during the London riots, providing real-time updates that television could not match.

Nearly eighty percent of young smartphone owners now regularly use social networking applications, but two-thirds utilize more than one platform; for instance, sixty percent access Facebook daily, yet forty-six percent opt for alternatives. "It's a complex scenario," remarks Benedict Evans, a digital media specialist. "All these apps leverage your smartphone. Some, like Instagram, endure; others fade away."

Thirteen-year-old Bennett owns three phones: he retains his BlackBerry for messaging, uses an iPhone for gaming, and makes calls on an Android device. His friends still rely on BBM. With just a few taps, you can send a single BlackBerry message to several hundred people; in contrast, WhatsApp limits this to 50 recipients. However, Instagram has emerged as a major social network for Bennett. "Instagram is Facebook without parents," he asserts. "Facebook is now for older folks." The low cost of purchasing and using a BlackBerry remains an advantage: anyone with a second-hand phone and a £7-a-month deal from a telecoms company can enjoy unlimited BBM messages. Yet, people no longer trust the privacy offered by BBM; businesspeople, revolutionaries, demonstrators, and rioters once believed their messages were secure. The subsequent arrests following the riots revealed that this was not the case.

In affluent London districts such as South Kensington, older pupils at one school predominantly use Apple phones and WhatsApp, a platform that offers features like location sharing and video calls, which BBM lacks. For many, BBM is a distant memory. "I still have a BlackBerry, but I'm the only one," remarks one teenager. How does this make him feel? "Isolated," he responds.

Source Text:
﻿A big international disagreement has started over the right of Bolivia’s indigenous Indian tribes to chew coca leaves, the main ingredient in cocaine. This could have a significant effect on global drugs policy. Bolivia has received a special exemption from the 1961 Convention on Drugs, the agreement that controls international drugs policy. The exemption allows Bolivia’s indigenous people to chew the leaves.
Bolivia said that the convention was against its new constitution, which says it must “protect native and ancestral coca” as part of its cultural heritage and says that coca “in its natural state … is not a dangerous drug”.
South American Indians have chewed coca leaves for hundreds of years. The leaves give energy and have medicinal qualities. People who support Bolivia’s position said that defending the rights of indigenous people was the right thing to do. “The Bolivian move is very important,” said Danny Kushlick, of the Transform Drug Policy Foundation. “It shows that any country that doesn’t want to continue the war on drugs can change its relations with the UN conventions.”
But the UN’s International Narcotics Control Board (INCB), which checks global drug agreements, says Bolivia may harm international drug controls. Many countries – including the UK, the US, Italy, Sweden, the Netherlands and Russia – do not want to give Bolivia what it is asking for.
The UK told the UN that it “respects the cultural importance of the coca leaf in Bolivia”, but it adds: “The United Kingdom is worried that the exemption could lead to more coca production and – most importantly – more coca reaching the cocaine trade. The exemption would make it more difficult to control the illegal drugs trade.”
The right of indigenous people in South America’s Andean region to chew coca leaf was removed in 1964 when Bolivia was under a dictatorship and it signed the convention.
In 2011, Bolivia told the UN that it did not want to be part of the convention any more. It is now part of the convention again, but with an exemption so that its indigenous people can continue chewing coca leaves.
The exemption is the first in the history of UN drug-control agreements. It has led to worries that other countries may also ask for exemptions. The Russian government says that the exemption will lead to more illegal cocaine and warns that “it also sets a dangerous example that could be used by other states in creating a more liberal drug-control regime”.
The British parliament has recommended that the UK government should support Bolivia’s request. It says that it is important that countries stay in the convention. Bolivia’s return could be blocked only if a third or more of the 184 countries that have signed the convention opposed the exemption. Some people believe that the US and UK are telling other countries that they should block Bolivia’s request.
Nancie Prud’homme, of the International Centre on Human Rights and Drug Policy, said people are wrong to oppose Bolivia’s request. “These objections are not completely legal,” she said. She added that, all over the world, it has become normal to support cultural and indigenous rights, so we should support Bolivia’s efforts.
The decision to ban coca chewing was based on a 1950 report. Some people say the report did not use any evidence. It is legal to grow coca leaves in Bolivia. As a result, cocaine production has decreased in the country and some experts see Bolivia as a model for other countries.
Rewritten Text:
A notable international controversy has emerged regarding the legal status of coca leaf consumption by Bolivia’s native inhabitants, a practice that holds profound heritage value for South America’s ancestral peoples. This disagreement could significantly impact global drug policy frameworks. Bolivia enjoys a unique position under the 1961 Convention on Drugs, an agreement that governs international narcotics control, due to its special exemption allowing the use of coca leaves by its indigenous populace.

According to Bolivia’s constitution, it is imperative to protect native and ancestral coca practices as integral components of cultural heritage. The document explicitly states that in its natural state, coca does not pose a hazardous threat. For decades, the Bolivian people have relied on coca leaves for their energizing effects and medicinal properties, which are well-documented in traditional healing practices.

Advocates supporting Bolivia’s stance argue that upholding the rights of indigenous communities is ethically justifiable. However, the International Narcotics Control Board (INCB), which oversees global drug accords, contends that granting such an exemption might undermine international drug control efforts. Numerous nations, including the United Kingdom, the United States, Italy, Sweden, the Netherlands, and Russia, oppose Bolivia’s request for this special dispensation.

For generations, the Bolivian people have utilized coca leaves not only for their energizing effects but also as a medicinal resource, practices that are deeply rooted in traditional healing rituals. The UK has expressed its concern over potential adverse effects, emphasizing that while it acknowledges the traditional importance of coca in Bolivia, it fears that such an exemption could exacerbate illicit drug trafficking.

Despite these concerns, the UK has expressed its support for Bolivia’s request, asserting the importance of maintaining membership in the convention. However, the decision to ban coca chewing was based on a 1950 report that some critics argue lacked scientific validation and moral imperatives. Despite this, it remains legally permissible for Bolivians to cultivate coca leaves, which has led to a reduction in cocaine production and positions Bolivia as an exemplary nation for others considering similar policies.

On the other hand, Nancie Prud’homme of the International Centre on Human Rights and Drug Policy argues that opposition to Bolivia’s request is unjustified from a legal standpoint. For decades, she contends, global trends increasingly support cultural and indigenous rights, thereby justifying Bolivia's efforts based on scientific validation and moral imperatives.

Source Text:
﻿Male bosses are paid bonuses double the size of bonuses given to female colleagues in the same jobs. This means that men get bonuses of £141,500 more than women over their working lives.
The numbers, released by the Chartered Management Institute (CMI), show that men in UK management jobs earned average bonuses of £6,442 in 2012 – compared with £3,029 for women.
Female directors received bonuses of £36,270 over the past 12 months, compared with £63,700 received by male directors.
The numbers show that pay in British business is still not equal. Campaigners believe we must do something to improve equality at work.
Ann Francke, the CMI’s chief executive, said that there should be more flexibility and less masculine cultures, and that the good work people do should be more important than how much time they spend in the office.
Also, there should be more transparency around performance and bonuses.
“If we solve this issue, we will improve the performance of organizations and the well- being of people at work,” she said. “What are we waiting for?”
Some of the numbers may be affected by women doing jobs where there is less of a culture of bonus payments. But the differences in the sizes of bonuses do make Britain’s pay gap worse. The government says the pay gap is closing but that full-time male employees still earn 10% more than women.
Maria Miller, the Minister for Women and Equalities, said that the CMI numbers are another example from the world of work that shows that women still earn less than men doing the same job.
“Changes in the workplace are happening and it’s good that the pay gap is closing – but there is still more to do before we see full equality in the workplace.
“The government is trying to help. 120 companies have joined our Think, Act, Report scheme, which encourages companies to improve the way they recruit, promote and pay women.
“We’ve also looked at other causes of the pay gap, such as having to juggle work and family.”
Large companies such as Tesco, BT, Unilever and the international law firm Eversheds are some of the companies that have signed up to Think, Act, Report. The scheme has only attracted 120 companies in nearly two years.
But the CMI’s numbers also showed that the pay gap is closing: the difference between the average salaries earned by male and female bosses appeared to be smaller than in 2012.
Rewritten Text:
In a comprehensive analysis of remuneration disparities within the managerial echelons of British enterprises, it has been revealed that male executives are awarded bonuses approximately twice as substantial as those received by their female counterparts occupying equivalent positions. Over an extended career trajectory, this translates to a differential in bonus earnings amounting to £141,500 more for men than women.

According to data released by the Chartered Management Institute (CMI), male executives garnered average bonuses of £6,442 in 2012, while their female colleagues received only £3,029. Female directors experienced a similar disparity, with bonuses totalling £36,270 over the past year compared to the £63,700 awarded to male executives.

These findings underscore the persistent inequities in pay within British business environments. Advocates for workplace equality argue that measures must be implemented to address these imbalances. According to Ann Francke, chief executive of the CMI, fostering a more flexible and less traditionally masculine corporate culture could mitigate such disparities; as she stated, "fostering a more flexible and less traditionally masculine corporate culture could help reduce these disparities." Furthermore, transparency regarding performance evaluations and bonus distributions is essential for addressing these disparities.

While some argue that these discrepancies might be influenced by women's participation in roles with less frequent bonus opportunities, the magnitude of the bonuses awarded to male executives exacerbates Britain’s existing pay gap. The government acknowledges this disparity but maintains that full-time male employees continue to earn 10% more than their female counterparts, despite performing equivalent tasks and contributing equally to company success.

Maria Miller, the Minister for Women and Equalities, highlighted that CMI's findings are indicative of broader trends in the workplace where women still receive lower compensation despite performing equivalent tasks. She noted that while progress is being made, significant strides remain to achieve full equality.

To address these issues, the government has initiated programs such as the Think, Act, Report scheme, which encourages companies to improve their practices in recruiting, promoting, and compensating women. This initiative has garnered support from 120 organizations, including large corporations such as Tesco, BT, Unilever, and Eversheds, which have committed to improving their practices in recruiting, promoting, and compensating women.

However, despite these efforts, the CMI's data also indicated a narrowing of the pay gap between male executives and female executives since 2012.

Source Text:
﻿More than 100,000 people went onto the streets in Brazil to show their anger at violent police, poor public services and high costs for the World Cup.
The demonstrations in Rio de Janeiro, São Paulo, Brasilia, Belem, Belo Horizonte and Salvador started peacefully, but there were some clashes with police and people set fire to cars and buses.
People complained that police used rubber bullets, tear gas and violent beatings. Happening at the start of the football Confederations Cup, the rallies brought together people who are angry with the high costs and poor quality of public services, the large amounts of money spent on international sporting events, low standards of health care, inequality and corruption.
Most of the demonstrations were peaceful, but several police were hurt, at least one car was burned and windows were broken.
People were demonstrating for different reasons. “We are here because we hate the government. They do nothing for us,” said Oscar José Santos, 19 years old.
“I’m an architect but I have been unemployed for six months. There must be something wrong with this country,” said Nadia al Husin.
At a smaller rally in Brasilia, demonstrators entered the high-security area of the national congress. Several climbed onto the roof.
In Belo Horizonte, police clashed with protesters who tried to get into a football stadium, where there was a Confederations Cup match between Nigeria and Tahiti.
In Porto Alegre, demonstrators set fire to a bus and, in Curitiba, protesters tried to enter the office of the state governor. There were also rallies in Belem, Salvador and other places.
In São Paulo, there were large groups of people but the marches were peaceful.
Most protesters were young and, for many, it was their first experience of such a giant rally. “My generation has never experienced this,” said Thiago Firbida, a student. “Since the dictatorship, Brazilians have never demonstrated like this. They did not believe they had a reason to. But now Brazil once again has problems, with a constant rise in prices, so people are finally reacting.”
Brazil’s demonstrations have been given special names – the “vinegar revolution” (because police arrested people for carrying vinegar to stop the effects of tear gas), the “20-cent revolution” (because of the bus price rise) and the Passe Livre (because of the demand for free public transport).
Some said the protests did not feel Brazilian but they were liberating. “Our politicians need to see the strength we have as one people. Brazilians are usually too nice; they enjoy partying, not protesting, but something is changing,” said Deli Borsar, a 53-year-old yoga teacher.
After people heard about the costs of new and improved stadiums on the news, the Confederations Cup football tournament has been one of the reasons for the protests. Before Saturday’s match in Brasilia, groups of demonstrators were dispersed by riot police. Frightened Japanese supporters ran from the area holding their children, when they heard shots – perhaps rubber bullets or tear gas.
Another protest march, near Rio’s Maracana Stadium, also had a heavy police response.
President Dilma Rousseff “believes peaceful protests are correct and proper for a democracy and that it is natural for young people to demonstrate.”
But people booed the president at the opening ceremony for the Confederations Cup. She will have serious political problems, both now and in 2014, when Brazil will host the World Cup and also have an election.
Rewritten Text:
In excess of one hundred thousand individuals took to the streets across various urban centers—such as Rio de Janeiro, São Paulo, Brasília, Belém, Belo Horizonte, and Salvador—to express their discontent with aggressive law enforcement tactics, poor infrastructure, underfunded education, and exorbitant expenses associated with hosting the World Cup. The initial demonstrations were largely peaceful; however, sporadic confrontations erupted between demonstrators and security forces, leading to the burning of several vehicles and buses.

The protesters alleged that authorities employed rubber bullets, tear gas, and physical assaults to quell their protests. These events coincided with the commencement of the football Confederations Cup, uniting individuals who were aggrieved by high costs and inadequate public services, substantial expenditures on international sporting events, substandard healthcare, pervasive inequality, and corruption.

While most rallies remained nonviolent, several law enforcement officers sustained injuries, at least one vehicle was torched, and windows were shattered. Participants cited diverse reasons for their actions: "We are here because we despise the government; they have done nothing for us," stated Oscar José Santos, a nineteen-year-old individual. "I am an architect but I have been unemployed for six months; something is clearly amiss with this nation," remarked Nadia al Husin.

In Brasília, smaller assemblies saw demonstrators breach the high-security perimeter of the national congress, with some ascending to the roof. In Belo Horizonte, clashes ensued between protesters attempting to enter a football stadium hosting a Confederations Cup match between Nigeria and Tahiti, where several vehicles were set ablaze. Meanwhile, in Porto Alegre, buses were set ablaze, while in Curitiba, demonstrators sought access to the governor's office. Smaller rallies also took place in Belem, Salvador, and other locations.

In São Paulo, large crowds assembled but maintained a peaceful demeanor; predominantly young protesters, many of whom had never experienced such extensive demonstrations before, expressed their sentiments: "My generation has never witnessed this; since the dictatorship, Brazilians have never protested on such a scale," declared Thiago Firbida, a student. "They did not believe they had grounds to protest, but now Brazil faces persistent inflationary pressures, prompting people's reactions."

In São Paulo, substantial gatherings convened and preserved their nonviolent nature; predominantly young protesters, many of whom had never experienced such extensive demonstrations before, expressed their sentiments: "My generation has never witnessed this; since the dictatorship, Brazilians have never protested on such a scale," declared Thiago Firbida, a student. "They did not believe they had grounds to protest, but now Brazil faces persistent inflationary pressures, prompting people's reactions."

Meanwhile, in Brasília, smaller assemblies saw demonstrators breach the high-security perimeter of the national congress, with some ascending to the roof. In Belo Horizonte, clashes ensued between protesters attempting to enter a football stadium hosting a Confederations Cup match between Nigeria and Tahiti, where several vehicles were set ablaze. Meanwhile, in Porto Alegre, buses were set ablaze, while in Curitiba, demonstrators sought access to the governor's office. Smaller rallies also took place in Belem, Salvador, and other locations.

Brazil’s protests garnered unique monikers: the “vinegar revolution” (due to arrests for carrying vinegar to mitigate tear gas effects), the “20-cent revolution” (stemming from increased bus fares), and Passe Livre (reflecting demands for free public transport). Some argued that these demonstrations did not conform to traditional Brazilian behavior, yet they were liberating. "Our politicians must recognize our collective strength as a unified people," asserted Deli Borsar, a fifty-three-year-old yoga instructor. "Brazilians are typically too complacent; they prefer celebration over protest, but change is occurring."

The Confederations Cup football tournament served as a catalyst for these protests, following reports of significant investments in new and improved stadiums. Prior to the match in Brasília, demonstrators were dispersed by riot police, causing Japanese supporters to flee with their children upon hearing shots—possibly rubber bullets or tear gas.

Another protest near Rio’s Maracanã Stadium also faced heavy police intervention. President Dilma Rousseff acknowledged that peaceful protests are legitimate within a democratic framework and noted the natural inclination of young people to demonstrate. However, she faced significant political challenges, both in the short term and ahead of the 2014 World Cup and concurrent elections.

Source Text:
﻿The European Parliament have said that health warnings will cover nearly two-thirds of cigarette packs and there will be a ban on menthol cigarettes in the EU.
The EU will ban menthol and other flavours from 2022. MEPs also decided that most electronic cigarettes, which are more and more popular as alternatives to normal cigarettes, do not to be need regulated in the same way as medicines.
The Department of Health and e-cigarette companies in Britain want to find out exactly what this means – for example, will e-cigarette companies be banned from advertising at sports events?
The Department of Health said: “We are very pleased to see tougher action on smoking, with European controls banning flavoured cigarettes and the introduction of stricter rules on health warnings on cigarette packs.
“But we are disappointed with the decision not to regulate nicotine-containing products (NCPs), including e-cigarettes, as medicines. We believe these products need to be regulated as medicines.
“Smoking levels in England are at their lowest since records began – 19.5 per cent – but we want to reduce the numbers of people smoking even more and believe this important step will help.”
UK e-cigarette companies, who were happy with the parliament’s vote, said they were already in talks with the Advertising Standards Authority. But they said that it would not be a good idea to ban all advertising.
MEPs decided e-cigarettes should only be regulated as medical products if the e-cigarette companies said they could stop people from smoking.
Other groups want e-cigarettes, used by about 1.3 million people in Britain, to be regulated in the same way as gums, patches and mouth sprays, which are aimed at helping smokers to quit.
The MEPs voted to put health warnings on 65% of each cigarette pack. At the moment, the warnings cover at least 30% on the front and 40% on the back. The UK government has not decided if they will do the same as Australia and introduce standardized packaging. First, they want to know that this will stop people from smoking.
The MEPs’ decision about the bigger health warnings on the packaging could become law in 2014.
“The UK continues to believe that medicinal regulation of NCPs is best for public health,” said the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Authority.
Linda McAvan, Labour MEP for Yorkshire and the Humber, said: “We know that it is children, not adults, who start smoking. There are fewer and fewer adult smokers in most EU countries, but there are more young smokers.”
Martin Callanan, the Conservative MEP for North East England, said that banning e-cigarettes would have been totally crazy. “These are products that have helped many people stop smoking more harmful cigarettes.”
British American Tobacco said the bigger health warnings were not necessary and that a ban on menthol cigarettes would make more people want to buy from the black market.
Rewritten Text:
The European Parliament has declared that health advisories will occupy approximately two-thirds of cigarette packaging surfaces, and a ban on menthol cigarettes will be implemented within the European Union (EU). By 2022, the EU intends to prohibit flavored cigarettes, including those with menthol additives, as part of its comprehensive tobacco control strategy. Meanwhile, electronic cigarettes, which are widely acknowledged as viable alternatives to traditional cigarettes due to their lower health risks and potential for reducing smoking rates, are subject to less stringent regulatory scrutiny compared to the strict controls imposed on medical devices.

Health outcomes in Britain and industry representatives from e-cigarette manufacturers are seeking clarification regarding the implications of these new regulations, particularly concerning advertising restrictions at sporting events, where potential impacts on well-being are of concern. The Department of Health expressed satisfaction with the enhanced anti-smoking measures but was disheartened by the decision not to regulate nicotine-containing products (NCPs), including electronic cigarettes, as pharmaceuticals. They argue that such regulation is essential for population health.

Furthermore, according to Labour MEP Linda McAvan, who highlighted the fact that smoking initiation primarily manifests among young individuals while adult smokers are becoming less common across most EU countries, the ban on e-cigarettes would be irrational. Conservative Member of the European Parliament (MEP) Martin Callanan contended that such a ban would be counterproductive, as these products assist many in quitting more harmful traditional cigarettes. British American Tobacco argued that larger health warnings and a ban on menthol cigarettes could drive consumers towards illicit markets, thereby undermining public health initiatives.

Furthermore, according to Labour MEP Linda McAvan, who highlighted the fact that smoking initiation primarily manifests among young individuals while adult smokers are becoming less common across most EU countries, the ban on e-cigarettes would be irrational. Conservative Member of the European Parliament (MEP) Martin Callanan contended that such a ban would be counterproductive, as these products assist many in quitting more harmful traditional cigarettes. British American Tobacco argued that larger health warnings and a ban on menthol cigarettes could drive consumers towards illicit markets, thereby undermining public health initiatives.

Health authorities in Britain and industry representatives from e-cigarette manufacturers are seeking clarification regarding the implications of these new regulations, particularly concerning advertising restrictions at sporting events, where potential impacts on well-being are of concern. The Department of Health expressed satisfaction with the enhanced anti-smoking measures but was disheartened by the decision not to regulate nicotine-containing products (NCPs), including electronic cigarettes, as pharmaceuticals. They argue that such regulation is essential for population health.
